captions.text:
People keep asking scientists, when are we
going to clone a mammoth? Look. We'll get

there when we get there. It's not the easiest
thing in the world!

Hello to all you living beings out there,
I'm Trace and you're watching DNews -- Extinction

happens. But it can really suck when an entire
species just dies out. Then again, so can

bringing back extinct things ah-la, Jurassic
Park...

If you haven't seen Jurassic Park // WHAT?
Go watch it! It's a CLASSIC. // cloning is

used to bring dinosaurs back from the dead.
Now, 20 years later, the technology is catching

up to the science fiction. We can CLONE EXTINCT
THINGS! And in the Internet Age, the Woolly
Mammoth seems to be the popular choice...

The mammoth became extinct 4,000 years ago,
but a 20-to-60-thousand-year-old tusk was

found in a construction pit in Seattle on
Valentine's Day! Due to its similarity to

elephants, some scientists think we can use
DNA from found parts to bring these bad boys

back to life. Though they sequenced the genome
of the woolly mammoth back in 2008. but do

you see any wandering around? Nope. Because
knowing the DNA structure isn't enough. Repairing

a damaged mammoth DNA strand using elephant
DNA would be excruciatingly slow and it's

pretty near impossible to tuck all six feet
of it into a microscopic cell nucleus. Last

year, a preserved mammoth carcass was discovered
in Siberia -- frozen in the ice. While digging

it out, a mis-aimed ice pick nicked its skin
and blood flowed out! So now scientists are

looking for an in-tact DNA-packed nucleus
of one of those red blood cells.

If they get one then BINGO. MAMMOTH DNA. Then
could use the same method used to clone Dolly

the sheep -- called somatic cell nuclear transfer.
Basically, they replace the nucleus in an

egg cell of a related animal with the nucleus
of the animal to be cloned. If it takes, scientists

implant the mammoth embry into a surrogate
mother -- likely an African Elephant. Next
stop de-extinction!

Though it all sounds relatively easy, it ain't.
There are a handful of teams working on cloning

extinct species, including mammoths, but so
far there's no luck. Nature has a tough time

preserving DNA and nuclei for science. Until
we find one, we'll just have to keep watching
Jurassic Park.

title: Are We Finally Ready To Clone A Mammoth?

comments.author: NIGHTMARE DEVASTATOR

comments.text:
Problem is they would most likely just turn out as living dolls, because as 
it stands they can't survive in the wild for all that long. Why? Food is 
hard to get and Mammoths need a large amount. And another Reason is - well 
it's getting warmer again. Hence their survival rate in would be quite low. 

Dodo would be a more likely candidate that can actually survive in the 
wild, and given the fact that we could tamper a bit with their DNA we could 
make it so that they would lay more than one egg a year. On top of that 
Dodos are big and meaty chickens, so there is a possibility of 
commercializing them - given the fact that we could make it so they lay 
more than one egg a year.

But the questions of all questions is: do we really need to clone a Mammoth 
or for that matter anything? Or bring extinct animals back? Because some 
went extinct for a reason (mammoth), some were just driven to extinction 
because of Man (Dodo, Moa, etc...) Would it be awesome to see a Mammoth? 
yeah. Would it serve a purpose other than being a symbol of the Human 
genious and arrogance?﻿

comments.text:
Ok dude. Don't fall for the stupid generalization that creationists believe 
the Earth is 6000 years old.

On a Muslim perspective...

The Islamic scripture, written 1400 years ago, had mention of the earth's 
roundness (compared to an ostrich egg), along with mention of the barrier 
between salt and sea water. It also made mention of "beasts who came before 
us" (ie. dinosaurs). Also, it has mentioned that there were over 124,000 
prophets throughout human history and generations.

With that said, it's impossible to have been done within 6,000 years. That 
eliminates the idea that the Earth is 6000 years old. 

I can't speak on behalf of Christians or Jews, however. I'd like to hear 
from them, however.

comments.author: Rhapso X

comments.text:
+Rhapso X
What happened was just bad luck

You need to read up on natural selection and darwinism. It's bad luck when 
an individual animal dies or even a small group of animals die. When an 
entire species dies it is not bad luck. So when I say " meant to be 
extinct" what I'm saying is natural selection weeded the species out of 
existence. They were not meant to be on this earth because they were
not fit enough to survive the conditions.
comments.author: writerconsidered

Today they would be safe because I'm sure they wouldn't be cloned if people 
didn't know anything about them. I don't understand what you mean by the 
were meant to be extinct. How could anything go extinct on purpose? 
Dinosaurs weren't meant to go extinct. What happened was just bad luck. If 
I didn't understand you're previous comment, explain more clearly.
comments.author: Rhapso X

comments.text:
+Rhapso X I'm sure humans played a part
mammoth extinction but these were not modern humans, they were truly human 
animals living  within the ego-system. Making the mammoth extinction a 
completely natural extinction. I'm sure there were other factors as well 
which caused their extinction. No one primary predator is the primary cause 
of an extinction. If that were the case then ego-systems would never be 
able to support predator prey systems to begin with.

So no I do not think we should try and fix
a completely natural extinction. Darwins
natural selection has spoken, the verdict is in.
The mammoth is supposed to be extinct by virtue of it's lack of presence.

If humans try to change that then we will be breaking 3 billion years of 
natural selection precedence. Considering we are the ones who discovered 
and explained this theory it would be foolish of us to simply dismiss and 
ignore this crucial point.
comments.author: writerconsidered

comments.text:

comments.author: Dave Krawn

comments.text:
They didn't go extinct because of the warming climate, in fact some 
scientist think they went extinct because it got colder and they couldn't 
stand it. Mammoths serve an ecological role, that hasn't been filled for 
thousands of years. They were responsible for the growth of grass in 
Russia, they trampled over weeds and bushes, which allowed grass to grow in 
those areas. When they are cloned, they will be sent to a Russian 
park(Pleistocene Park) filled with certain animals that were around during 
the time of the mammoth to recreate the ice age ecosystem(Siberian tigers, 
bison, horses, muck ox, elk, moose, leopards, camels, etc).
comments.author: Ate Scaladferri
